Question_1.Context: The paper discusses the concept of cracks in materials and their formation due to the breakage of atomic bonds.
Question_1.Question: What is the reason why even closed cracks are visible by a naked eye?
Question_1.A: Material flow out of the system
Question_1.Source: The latter, in our opinion, is the reason why even closed cracks are visible by a naked eye. Thus, material flows out of the system during the fracture process.

Question_2.Context: The paper discusses the formulation of coupled mass and momenta balance equations for describing fracture.
Question_2.Question: What is the focus of the paper regarding fracture?
Question_2.Source: Our focus is on brittle fracture and we propose a finite strain hyperelastic thermodynamic framework for the coupled mass-flow-elastic boundary value problem.

Question_3.Context: The paper introduces the concepts of cohesive zone models (CZMs) and Continuum Damage Mechanics (CDM) for material failure modeling.
Question_3.Question: What is the main difference between cohesive zone models (CZMs) and Continuum Damage Mechanics (CDM)?
Question_3.A: CZMs focus on bulk material failure, while CDM focuses on surface failure.
Question_3.B: CZMs use damage variables, while CDM does not.
Question_3.C: CDM uses phase fields, while CZMs do not.
Question_3.D: CDM is based on mass conservation, while CZMs are not.
Question_3.Source: Surface failure models are known by the name of cohesive zone models (CZMs). In the latter case, continuum is enriched with discontinuities along surfaces—cohesive zones— with additional traction-displacement-separation constitutive laws.

Question_4.Context: The paper discusses the challenges with numerical simulations based on bulk failure laws.
Question_4.Question: What issue arises with numerical simulations based on bulk failure laws?
Question_4.Source: Unfortunately, numerical simulations based on the bulk failure laws show the so-called pathological mesh sensitivity, which means that the finer meshes lead to the narrower damage localization areas.

Question_5.Context: The paper introduces nonlocal continuum formulations to address mesh sensitivity issues.
Question_5.Question: What is the purpose of using nonlocal continuum formulations?
Question_5.Source: To surmount the latter pitfall gradient- or integral- type nonlocal continuum formulations are used where a characteristic length is incorporated to limit the size of the spatial failure localization.

Question_6.Context: The paper discusses the concept of cracks in materials and their formation due to the breakage of atomic bonds.
Question_6.Question: What is the characteristic size of the volume where bond breakage occurs?
Question_6.Source: Therefore, the physical basis for the nonlocal models appears disputable. A more physically based treatment of the pathological mesh sensitivity of the bulk failure simulations should likely include multi-physics coupling.

Question_7.Context: The paper discusses the formulation of the coupled mass-flow-elastic initial boundary value problem.
Question_7.Question: What is the switch parameter ζ used for in the constitutive law for the mass source?
Question_7.Source: The switch parameter ζ, which is necessary to prevent material healing, will be explained below.

Question_8.Context: The paper discusses the constitutive law for the Lagrangean mass flux.
Question_8.Question: What is the purpose of the exponential factor in the constitutive law for the Lagrangean mass flux?
Question_8.B: To suppress diffusion in failed material
Question_8.Source: The exponential factor is necessary in (21) to suppress diffusion in the failed material.

Question_9.Context: The paper discusses the formulation of the coupled mass-flow-elastic initial boundary value problem.
Question_9.Question: What is the characteristic length l in the constitutive law for the mass source?
Question_9.Source: where l = � κ/β is the characteristic length, which might depend on the deformation process.

Question_10.Context: The paper discusses the formulation of the coupled mass-flow-elastic initial boundary value problem.
Question_10.Question: What is the physical interpretation of the switch parameter ζ in the constitutive law for the mass source?
Question_10.Source: Parameter ζ ≤ 0 is not an internal variable. It is a switch: ζ = 0 for the reversible process; and ζ < 0 for the irreversibly failed material and dissipated strain energy.
